However, heavy oil deactivates zeolite catalysts easily, which is not conducive to raw material conversion and quality improvement. With the increase of industrial capacity, the output of spent catalysts is also increasing year by year, which puts forward higher requirements for the catalyst deactivation mechanism and regeneration process. In this paper, the deactivation mechanisms of zeolite catalyst in heavy oil catalytic cracking were clarified, and the anti-deactivation methods of zeolite catalyst, such as modification, structure regulation, use of additives, and machine learning assists in catalyst design were summarized, and the corresponding catalyst regeneration methods were proposed. It is a hot topic to apply the pore classification and nanocrystallization of catalyst, which provides a reference for the application of heavy oil catalytic cracking catalyst. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Heavy oil Catalytic cracking Zeolite Deactivation Regeneration Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction In Fig. 1, China's oil consumption increased by 7.3% over the previous year, accounting for about 19.5% of total energy consumption, second only to coal in 2021. China's heavy crude oil production has accelerated in recent years, accounting for about 1/10 of the annual oil production [1]. Such a high output of heavy crude oil makes it a big problem how to make high-value and clean use. Residue fluid catalytic cracking (RFCC) technology can treat heavy oil well. It is flexible enough to selectively adjust product distribution, such as from diesel to gasoline, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), and olefins [2]. According to statistics, more than 46% of the world's refineries have adopted FCC technology for lightening crude oil [3]. As an important product of the FCC process, more than 30% of propylene in China comes from FCC [4]. At the same time, the world's propylene demand is growing at 4–5% per year [5], of which the FCC process meets 25–30% [6]. Therefore, RFCC technology is a major issue for heavy oil feeds in China and the world's oil refining industry [7]. As shown in Fig. 2, heavy oil generally refers to liquid oil with an American petroleum institute (API) gravity less than 20° or a density value greater than 0.9340 g/cm3 (15 °C), including heavy crude and heavy fractions from conventional crude oil through distillation, such as atmospheric residue and vacuum residue [1]. In addition, coal/biomass pyrolysis tar also belongs to heavy oil [8,9]. Table 1 summarizes the properties of several heavy oils. As shown in Table 1, the resins + asphaltenes contents in heavy oils are generally between 20% and 50% [10,11]. Table 1 shows that the total acid number (TAN) of heavy oil is significantly higher than that of conventional crude (usually 1 mg KOH/g) [12]. Heavy oil also has the characteristics of high carbon residue, high metal contents (Fe, Ni, V, Ca, and Na), high sulfur content, and low H/C [10]. The catalyst is one of the research cores on heavy oil catalytic cracking. The catalysts for heavy oil catalytic cracking mainly include metal catalysts and zeolite catalysts. Among them, zeolite catalyst is the most widely used, which is a porous solid catalyst. Most oil companies will choose zeolite catalysts in their catalytic cracking process. The earliest zeolite catalysts were mainly A, X, and Y-type catalysts. With the elimination of X-type zeolite catalysts, high stability and activity zeolite catalysts such as USY, ZSM-5, SPAO, MCM, SBA, and β-type zeolite catalysts, gradually appeared in people's vision [14]. However, only Y zeolite catalysts and ZSM-5 zeolite catalysts have been widely used in the petroleum industry. With the development of cracking technology and reactor, the conversion rate of feedstocks has reached more than 80% [3]. Most RFCC zeolite catalysts consist of zeolite, clay, matrix, and additives. Zeolite is the main active component [15]. Its acid sites and porous structure can convert larger molecules into gasoline-range molecules [16–22]. The porous structure helps slow down the deactivation of zeolite. Clay as filler contributes little to the surface area and activity of the catalyst. The matrix is synthesized by various alumina and silica sources, allowing the feedstocks' macromolecules to enter and pre-crack. Binders can improve the mechanical properties of zeolite catalysts required for operation in RFCC units. Additives help RFCC catalysts maintain efficient and stable performance. However, heavy oil has a high density, high carbon yield and contains many compounds such as organic metal compounds, macromolecular alkanes, polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, and macromolecular heteroatom organic compounds, which can easily lead to catalyst deactivation. The deactivation process of the zeolite catalysts is shown in Fig. 3. Adverse reaction conditions destroy the catalyst's physical and chemical structure, block the catalyst's pores, and cover the catalyst's active sites, thereby reducing the conversion rate and making the product quality worse. The large molecular weight groups of unconverted feedstock and undesirable cracking products deposit on the surface and pores of the catalyst, which promotes coking and further deactivates the catalyst. Catalyst deactivation decreases the conversion rate of feedstocks and product selectivity, increases equipment burdensome, affects petroleum companies' production capacity, and causes waste of feedstocks. In addition, RFCC spent catalyst (S-Cat) resources will cause environmental pollution and waste of resources, so treating and recycling them is of great significance. As shown in Fig. 4, typical RFCC units consist of a reactor and regenerator. The zeolite catalysts are cycled in the units, during which some particles are broken and deactivated, resulting in the loss of effective catalytic particles [23]. In addition, for some feedstocks with high metal content and high density or viscosity, to keep the units stable and the reactivity and selectivity of the catalyst, it is necessary to regularly remove a portion of the inventory and add a certain amount of fresh catalyst to form an equilibrium catalyst (E-Cat), thus, keep the deactivation rate at an acceptable level [24,25]. It is estimated that the world produces about 2300 tons of FCC catalysts per day, equivalent to 840,000 tons per year [3]. The world's daily production of S-Cat is as high as 200,000–400,000 tons, and the fresh catalyst addition needed to maintain the inventory activity reaches 1400 t/d globally [2,26]. For heavy oil feedstocks, the amount of S-Cat produced by RFCC is huge. The regenerator mainly uses coke-burning regeneration to improve the catalyst life in the production process [27]. However, after several regenerations, the catalytic activity is irretrievably compromised [23,25]. Besides, the heavy metals, heteroatoms, and coke deposition can cause blockage, collapse, and coverage of the catalytically active sites. The deactivation of zeolite catalysts caused by these has not been effectively solved. For S-Cat, traditional landfill disposal will cause environmental pollution and increase production costs [28]. Therefore, it is urgent to solve the problems of catalyst deactivation and regeneration. This paper reviewed the deactivation reasons and the methods of anti-deactivation and regeneration of RFCC zeolite catalysts. The deactivation reasons include reversible deactivation, irreversible deactivation, and additives/matrix deactivation, in which the different formation mechanisms of coke types, attrition mechanisms, and poison mechanisms of heteroatoms and metal atoms are discussed. On this basis, our work further studied anti-deactivation methods. The methods include loading modification, regulation of particle size and structure, additives, modification of other components (matrix, clay, binder), and machine learning, in which machine learning as a new method to assist RFCC catalyst design and optimization is deeply discussed. The regeneration methods include coke burning regeneration, chemical regeneration, and magnetic separation, in which only coke burning regeneration has been widely applied in industry. 2 Research progress on deactivation of zeolite catalysts The deactivation reasons of zeolite catalysts include physical and chemical. Physical causes include sintering, occlusion, and loss of active surface. Chemical causes include chemical degradation, poisoning, and fouling. The zeolite catalyst deactivation can be divided into reversible deactivation, irreversible deactivation, and additives deactivation [2]. Reversible deactivation generally refers to the deactivation caused by coking and heteroatom-containing molecules, which does not mean that zeolite deactivation is fully reversible. Irreversible deactivation mainly refers to the zeolite structure changes caused by metal poisoning and hydrothermal dealumination [29]. The physical deconstruction of catalysts caused by attrition also belongs to irreversible deactivation. 2.1 Reversible deactivation 2.1.1 Coking deactivation The coking deactivation is mainly caused by coke composed of macromolecular condensed aromatic compounds under high-temperature conditions of the heavy oil cracking process [30]. Coke deposits in the mesopores of the matrix and the binder [31]. As shown in Fig. 3, coke can cause pore blockage [32] and cover catalytic sites [25]. The study shows that in the catalyst, 32% of coke was deposited on the RFCC catalyst surface, 41% of coke was deposited in the micropores, and 27% of coke was deposited in the mesopores [6]. According to the source and location of the coke and coking process in the RFCC units, Cerqueira et al. [2] divided the types of coke into catalytic coke, catalyst-to-oil coke, thermal coke, additive coke, and contaminant coke. Coke types in RFCC also are divided into thermal coke (a free radical mechanism) and catalytic coke (carbocation mechanism, metal catalytic mechanism) based on the coke generation mechanisms. The coke produced by the reaction of hydrocarbons on the acid sites of the catalysts follows the carbocation mechanism, an important coke generation pathway in RFCC. As shown in Fig. 5, Appleby [33] et al. found that coke generated increased with the increasing basicity of the feedstock because the electrons of N in the heavy oil feedstock bond with the Lewis (L) acid sites or capture the proton of the Bronsted (B) acid sites in the catalyst and then highly condensed with other aromatic, which promoted coke generation [7,34]. The coke generated under RFCC conditions (500–550 °C) is a polyaromatic substance, so forming aromatic rings is the initial stage of generating catalytic coke [2]. As shown in Fig. 6, alkanes are first cracked into C6- olefins, then C6+ olefins are generated by oligomerization. Then, a hydrogen transfer reaction occurs on active sites of the zeolite catalyst to generate diolefins, which oligomerize into naphthenes, and the naphthenes via isomerization and three hydrogen transfer reactions forming aromatics. The oligomerization of aromatic with unsaturated hydrocarbons such as olefins/aromatics is repeated continuously to generate coke [2]. In addition to the catalytic coke generated by the carbocation mechanism, the coking caused by metal catalysis is also an important reason for catalyst deactivation. As shown in Fig. 7, Bayraktar et al. [35] believed that the deposition of metal contaminants from the hydrocarbon feed causes the deactivation of the RFCC catalyst used in petroleum refining. The metal contaminants on the cracking catalyst promote excessive hydrogen and coke makes at the expense of gasoline. Carbon is continuously deposited between metal and carbon to form metal catalytic coke. In addition, Pieck et al. [30,36] found that the coke produced by dehydrogenation reaction on the metals of the zeolite catalysts contains more hydrogen than the coke produced by carbocation reaction on the acid sites of the catalysts. Coke produced by dehydrogenation catalyzed by metals in heavy oil (Fe, Ni, V) and stable sulfide is an important reason for pore blockage and deactivation of catalysts [16]. The study shows that the coking deactivation mechanisms of zeolite catalysts caused by vanadium and nickel are different. The former is controlled by acidity, while the latter is not [37]. The mechanism of coke formation by nickel is that the dehydrogenation reaction produces reactive paraffin (unsaturated hydrocarbons), which undergo rapid beta-scission or cyclo-condensations reactions, leading to the formation of coke, and coke yield increases linearly with the increase of Ni deposition [38]. On the contrary, excessively high vanadium deposition reduces the coke yield [37,39], which may result from V destroying the acid sites of zeolite [40]. The organic Fe in the heavy oil forms iron clusters composed of tiny iron oxide crystals on the RFCC catalyst particles to catalyze the dehydrogenation reaction, leading to a higher coke selectivity, and coke yield increases exponentially with the increasing iron content [16]. In Fig. 8, the coking mechanisms in RFCC are divided into heterogeneous catalytic, heterogeneous noncatalytic, and homogeneous noncatalytic mechanisms [41]. In the RFCC process, the small molecule free radicals in the gas phase and the large molecule free radicals in the liquid phase are converted into each other's phase through cracking, polymerization, dehydrogenation, and other reactions, then generate coke precursors, which further grow and adhere to the catalyst surface or deposit in the pores. The small molecule free radicals in the gas phase react to form tar droplets, and part of them stay in the gas phase and undergo pyrolysis, causing the surface of the droplets to coke, then become a mixture of tar and semi-char. Part of the pyrolysis gas generated by the tar droplets returned to the gas phase for secondary reactions. The droplets of the tar-char mixture adhere to the coke surface and combine with the coke, promoting the coke layer growth. In addition, molecules in the gas and liquid phases may undergo catalytic coking and gradually grow on the catalyst surface. As a result, during the RFCC process, coke may be formed on the external surface and pores of the catalyst, which block the pores and cover the active sites of the zeolite catalysts. In addition to catalytic coke, coke deposited in RFCC catalysts also includes some thermal coke (following a radical mechanism) [42,43]. However, compared with catalytic coke, thermal coke has a lower proportion due to the lower temperature in reactor [2]. Therefore, the influence caused by thermal coke can be ignored during coking deactivation of RFCC catalyst. 2.1.2 Heteroatomic deactivation Heteroatom deactivation mainly refers to the deactivation of catalysts caused by heteroatoms such as N, O, and S, among which N is the most poisonous to zeolite catalysts. In the RFCC process, the stable heteroatom compounds block the zeolite pores and cover the active sites [44]. Some of them react with acid sites, which lower the catalytic ability of the zeolite catalyst [45]. As shown in Fig. 9, there are three main mechanisms for nitrogen poisoning of zeolite catalysts. The first is that the nitrogen-containing compounds are chemically adsorbed on the catalyst's coordination of unsaturated Al or Si (L acid sites). The base nitrogen is adsorbed on L acid sites by electron pairing [2]. The second is that the nitrogen-containing compounds interact with hydrogen protons provided by the B acid sites, decreasing activity and deactivating the zeolite catalyst. In addition, Corma et al. [46] believed that the basic nitrogen species poison the active sites through the inductive effect. The basic nitrogen compounds such as pyridine molecules anchored to the protons lead to the proton's charge density strongly decreasing. Meanwhile, part of the electronic of the basic molecule is transmitted to the nearest acid sites (protonic acid) by inductive effect, which changes its initial charge density and makes it insufficient to catalyze the cracking reaction. Young et al. [47] found that basic nitrogen compounds in RFCC feedstocks generally exist in the form of stable compounds of polycyclic aromatic, which are easy to chemically adsorb on the acid sites of the catalyst surface and are difficult to react. Therefore, basic nitrogen compounds can easily generate coke precursors on the adsorption sites and further react to generate coke, covering the active sites, and decreasing the activity of catalyst zeolites. For the high-basic nitrogen RFCC feedstocks, studies have shown that the high zeolite content contributes to the high light product yield and decreased catalyst deactivation rate. In addition, the presence of acid sites, high surface area, and a broad pore size distribution in the catalyst matrix are all beneficial in the cracking of high-basic nitrogen feedstocks [48,49]. Stable organic and metal compounds containing S and O also deactivate zeolite catalysts. The Study [50] shows that sulfur species are bound to metal species on the outer surface of the zeolite support to prevent the heavy feedstock molecules into the zeolite pores, inhibiting key steps in cracking. However, sulfur poisoning is temperature-dependent, and catalyst activity is recovered upon increasing reaction temperature to 400 °C. In addition, the alkaline treatment greatly improves both the sulfur tolerance and the performance of the zeolite catalyst. The catalyst activity is recovered after the regenerator removes sulfur in RFCC. Kim et al. [51] found that in cracking, the aromatic sulfur compounds do not degrade the catalytic activity by sulfur poisoning but rather by accelerated coke formation. In addition, the sulfur polymers in heavy oil have low fluidity and high stability, blocking the pores of zeolite catalysts and promoting coking and deactivation [52]. 2.2 Irreversible deactivation 2.2.1 Metal poisoning As shown in Fig. 3, heavy oil contains many metal elements (V, Ni, Fe, Na, Ca, Zn, Pb, Cu, Cd, Cr, Co, Sb, Te, K, Hg, Au, and Ag), which can cause irreversible deactivation of the catalyst [16,28,53]. Different sources of crude oil have different types and contents of metals [6]. As shown in Table 2, Bai et al. [6] summarized the state, location, and effects of metal poisons. Ni and V are the most poisonous metals to catalysts in heavy oil [54]. Ali et al. [55] believed that the existing forms of metals (Fe, Ni, V) in heavy oil and catalysts are mainly metalloporphyrins and sulfides. They usually deposit on the catalyst surface, form metal compounds, block the pores, or migrate and react with the zeolite framework to destroy the zeolite structure (decreasing UCS (unit cell size), crystallinity, specific surface area, destroying acid sites) [37,56]. 2.2.1.1 Ni contaminant Ni in heavy feedstocks first deposits on the catalyst surface, causing partial deactivation. Then, Ni forms crystalline sulfides [59] and oxides [6] that make the surface layer thicker and migrate into the porous structure, ultimately deactivating the catalyst. In addition, Ni continuously promotes the hydrogen transfer to form coke, covering the catalyst pore surface and blocking the catalyst pores. Dreiling et al. [60] found that the reaction of NiO in E-Cat with steam increased the acidity of the catalyst, while the reaction with protons decreased the acid strength. In the presence of non-framework aluminum and other cations (Na+ and La3+), nickel is enriched on the external surface of the zeolite component, and it rarely migrates to the interior of the particles [61]. On commercial RFCC catalysts, nickel uniformly distributes the zeolite surface, and steam aging causes nickel to migrate from the zeolite surface into the matrix. 2.2.1.2 V contaminant The V poisoning mechanism is not precise yet. Most scholars believe that the migration of V and the zeolite structure destruction caused by vanadic acid deactivate the catalysts [62]. Akah [63] summarized the possible deactivation mechanisms of zeolite catalysts caused by V, including the direct vanadic acid mechanism, the indirect vanadic acid mechanism, and the mechanism of NaOH formation from vanadate. The main difference between the first two mechanisms is the different transformation mechanisms of easily transferable V2O5 in the RFCC units. The first mechanism believes that V2O5 directly generates vanadic acid with the water in the reactant (see Eqs. 1 and 2). The second mechanism believes that V2O5 indirectly generates vanadic acid after combining with the acid sites on the zeolite (see Eqs. 3, 4, and 5). In addition, the vanadate formed by vanadic acid is further hydrolyzed to form NaOH, causing the zeolite structure to collapse (see Eqs. 6 and 7), the amount of acid sites to decrease, and UCS to shrink. Pompea et al. [64] also show that vanadium attacks the rare earth (RE) component of the zeolite Y, forming a low melting point RE-vanadate phase and taking oxygen in the zeolite structure, thus destroying the zeolite structure. However, a certain vanadium concentration inhibits the hydrogen transfer reaction and promotes the dehydrogenation reaction, which improves the naphtha octane numbers [65,66]. (1) V2O5+3 H2O ↔ 2 H3VO4 (2) V2O5+H2O ↔ 2HVO3 (3) V2O5+2 H+-Y ↔ 2VO2+-Y+H2O (4) VO2+-Y+2 H2O ↔ H+-Y+H3VO4 (5) VO2+-Y+H2O ↔ H+-Y+HVO3 (6) NaVO3+H2O → HVO3+NaOH (7) 2NaOH+[SiO]3Al(HO)Si → NaAlO2+4[SiOH] 2.2.1.3 Fe contaminant The mobility of iron is low, and most of the deposited iron remains on the surface of the catalyst particle in the form of Fe2+/Fe3+ [67,68]. Mathieu et al. [16] found that iron contamination decreases catalyst activity by two mechanisms. At low iron concentrations, the deactivation is mainly due to the direct poisoning of acid sites. At higher iron concentrations, the deactivation is mainly due to pore blocking, and access of reactants to the internal active sites is hindered, with concomitant loss of substrate conversion. The loss of the RFCC catalyst activity by iron is due to the decreased accessibility of acid sites, poisoning of acid sites, and direct exchange with active sites. Studies have shown that iron contamination does not alter or severely disrupt the porous structure of the E-Cat, but leads to a significant decrease in the total catalyst acidity, possibly due to ion exchange between Fe and the catalyst's active sites [6]. 2.2.1.4 Ca contaminant Studies have shown that the mobility of nickel, iron, and calcium between and within the catalyst particles is low [69], and the distribution of calcium contamination is not as uniform as nickel on alumina and vanadium on zeolites [70]. The interaction and exchange phenomenon between zeolite-H+ and Ca2+ lower the hydrothermal stability of the catalyst, leading to the collapse of the zeolite structure and the decrease of the catalyst's total acidity [16]. In addition, the coke formation increases with iron can enhance the temperature in the regenerator, leading to further adverse effects of calcium. With the increase of calcium content, the surface area and the number of active sites of the catalyst decreased, and the crystallinity and acidity of the zeolite catalyst also decreased, which reduced the catalytic activity. At low calcium concentrations, most calcium does not interact with zeolite. Instead, it synergically binds with Fe to form low melting temperature phases on the surface of E-Cat, leading to pore blockage hence restricting the transport of large hydrocarbon feed molecules [71]. However, both catalyst activity and selectivity are significantly inhibited at very high calcium concentrations. 2.2.1.5 Na contaminant Studies have shown that sodium deposits on the surface of RFCC catalyst and accumulates on zeolite [6]. The Na+ ion exchange with protons neutralizes B acid and promotes the structure destruction of zeolite [72–74]. The specific surface area of the RFCC catalyst decreases with the decrease of zeolite surface area as the catalyst structure collapses due to Na+. Xu et al. [53] found that high Na+ concentration promotes hydrothermal deactivation and leads to the structural collapse of zeolite. In addition, the NaOH formed by sodium particles and water vapor further damages the zeolite structure. With increasing Na+ concentration, zeolite amorphize irreversibly, and the crystallinity and amount of micropores of the zeolite decrease without substantial depletion of framework Al [75]. Since sodium is not selective to a particular acid site, sodium poisoning may reduce heavy oil conversion but has little effect on heavy oil selectivity [72,73]. 2.2.1.6 K contaminant Due to the high content of potassium in biogenic feedstocks [76], studies have shown that poisoning by potassium is an important reason of zeolite catalysts deactivation in the cracking of biogenic heavy crude feedstocks [77,78]. Lin et al. [79] found that the peaks of spent catalysts loaded with potassium corresponding to weak and strong acid sites were significantly reduced compared to fresh HZSM-5 zeolite after catalytic pyrolysis of waste corn stover and high-density polyethylene. And with the increasing potassium concentration, the peak intensity of weak acid sites increased while the peak intensity of strong acid sites had no significant change. The results of Okado et al. [80] also demonstrate that potassium can attenuate the Brønsted acidity of the zeolite, leading to rapid poisoning of acid sites on zeolite catalysts [57,81]. Although biogenic heavy crude feedstocks are potential FCC feedstocks, they have not gained full prominence and implementation [6]. 2.2.2 Hydrothermal deactivation The high-temperature steam condition can remove the zeolite framework atoms (mainly Al), which causes damage to the zeolite structure and catalyst UCS shrinkage, thereby decreasing the activity and selectivity of RFCC catalyst [82,83]. In 1977, Chester and Stover [84] studied the hydrothermal deactivation kinetics of three Y-type zeolite catalysts by using a fluidized bed and found that the catalysts were deactivated mainly due to the change of the matrix in the low-temperature range of 594–732 °C, while the hydrothermal deactivation of zeolite was the main reason in the high-temperature range of 732–843 °C. Chen et al. [85–87] found that temperatures, water partial pressures, and aging time are important factors affecting the hydrothermal deactivation of cracking catalysts. They proposed three mathematical equations between relative crystallinity and temperatures, water partial pressures, and aging time, respectively. Fig. 10 summarizes the data of Chen et al. [86,88] and found that the remaining zeolite in catalyst decreases with the increasing temperature, water vapor partial pressure, and aging time, which may be an important reason for the decrease of catalyst cracking activity [86]. Nguyen et al. [89] found that the higher the steam content, the lower the surface area, crystallinity, acidity, and other physical and chemical properties of the zeolite catalyst, which leads to decreasing catalyst activity, and a 10 wt% increment in steam content resulted in 1.5 wt% decreases in the conversion of vacuum gas oil (VGO). The study of Francisco et al. [88] shows that temperatures and time were important reasons for the decrease of UCS and specific surface area of the catalyst under a certain water partial pressure, which indicated that hydrothermal conditions not only destroyed the unit cell structure of the zeolite but also caused pore collapse and blockage, affecting the acid sites distribution. In addition, many studies show that Na and V destruct zeolite framework synergistically under regenerator conditions [90,91], and the formation of NaOH was the rate-determining step [90], while RE metals inhibit catalyst deactivation to a certain extent [90,92]. The synergistic mechanism is shown in Fig. 11. The synergy maybe because some vanadium ions can promote the formation of NaOH [93]. Although hydrothermal conditions destroy the zeolite structure, it also increases the amount of mesopores in the zeolite and matrix, which is beneficial for the catalytic cracking of heavy oil [94]. Therefore, reasonable control of temperature, water partial pressure, reaction time, and modified catalysts are effective methods to prevent catalyst deactivation. 2.2.3 Physical deconstruction The physical deconstruction of FCC catalysts through attrition can cause the loss of effective catalytic particles. Attrition is divided into abrasion and fragmentation [95,96]. Abrasion usually occurs at the particle surface due to lateral cracks and surface wear, and is featured by the generation of a large amount of fines hard to capture by cyclones, whereas the change of particle size distribution (PSD) is negligible [96]. Fragmentation refers to breaking catalyst particles into smaller pieces of similar size. The attrition mechanism of the RFCC catalyst is a mixture of these two mechanisms in different proportions [95]. The main causes of particle attrition are fluid-dynamic-induced stresses such as mechanical impacts, stresses due to chemical reactions, and thermal stresses resulting in a change of internal pressure [97]. It has been found that the attrition of catalyst particles in an RFCC fluidized-bed reactor can come from the high-velocity jet by the air grid, bubble-induced particle motion, and cyclones [98]. The attrition index (AI) is an important index of RFCC zeolite catalyst, which is affected by particle properties (size, density, surface roughness, shape, microcracks size, hardness, and mechanical strength), operating conditions (temperature, pressure, gas velocity), and fluidized-bed structural parameters (orifice number and diameter for multi-orifice distributor plates, and bed height) [99–101]. The commercial FCC catalysts have an AI less than 3.5% ∙ h-1 [102]. Wu et al.'s study shows that increasing the hardness and mechanical strength of RFCC catalyst can significantly reduce its AI [95]. The particle shapes and surface features have little effect on attrition resistance but can influence attrition mechanisms. In the RFCC unit, catalyst particles with regular shapes are forced similarly in all directions during attrition. Thus fragmentation takes place less frequently when more particles contact other particles or tube walls, while fragmentation occurs to particles of irregular shapes, and the rougher the surfaces are, the more easily abrasion occurs. Werther et al. [103] suggested that the attrition of catalysts at high temperatures might be due to the thermal shock and the variation of particle and gas properties. Hao et al. [96] studied the attrition behavior of FCC catalysts from room temperature to 600 °C. The results showed that the AI decreased linearly with increasing temperature, and the attrition mode changed to be dominated by abrasion, which may be because that at room temperature, the catalyst particles are brittle and easy to break down into similar sizes because the cracks on the surface will develop readily. The material is softer at high temperatures than at room temperature, and the particles become more resistant to mechanical impact. 2.3 Deactivation of additives and matrix Additives are an important part of RFCC catalyst, which can significantly improve catalyst performance and help the catalyst resist deactivation and regenerate [2]. The additives include combustion promoters [104], recracking additives [105], additives to reduce gasoline sulfur [106], additives to reduce SOx [107] and NOx [108,109] emissions, poisonous metal traps [110,111], and some additives that enhance the mechanical properties of the catalysts [112]. In the RFCC process, additives and zeolite catalysts usually undergo cracking, stripping, and regeneration cycles in mechanical mixing, so feed composition, catalyst composition, and operational conditions are all important reasons for the additive deactivation. The deactivation mechanisms of additives include pore collapse, loss of specific surface area of the support, and metal sintering and oxidation state changes. Combustion promoters are the most widely used additives globally to favor the oxidation of CO in the regenerator dense phase, significantly improving the regeneration efficiency of zeolite catalysts [109,113]. Most commercial combustion promoters contain between 300 and 800 ppm of platinum, supported on alumina or mixed oxides [104], which occur hydrothermal deactivation under severe RFCC conditions. In addition, the high-temperature conditions of the regenerator may lead to the sintering of the active metal, reducing the available metallic surface and resulting in the additive's deactivation [2]. In addition to applying combustion promoters, SOx and NOx reduction additives are also significant for RFCC emission reduction [107]. Recracking additives such as ZSM-5-based additives have a lower tendency to form coke than Y zeolite because of its lower acid site density and smaller micropores network [2], which can increase the light olefins yield and gasoline octane numbers [54,105,114]. The main cause of ZSM-5 additives deactivation is dealumination due to the presence of steam at high temperatures (>8% steam, >700 ℃) [82,115]. However, the ZSM-5 zeolite structure does not collapse under hydrothermal conditions, and its physical properties do not change significantly with deactivation [94]. ZSM-5 additives have better resistance to metal contamination than Y zeolite, and a low metal deposition level does not significantly affect the ZSM-5 zeolite structure [116]. ZSM-5 lost its crystallinity far less than the Y zeolite at an equivalent V level [117], which may be due to the less influence of V on ZSM-5 due to its aluminum-poor structure. RFCC gasoline sulfur reduction additives are mainly supported metal oxides having L acid properties, such as Zn, Zr, Co, Ni, or Mn impregnated on alumina, hydrotalcite, titania, or Mg(Al)O [106]. The study shows that the deactivation of gasoline sulfur reduction additives is closely related to hydrothermal conditions and zeolite components [118]. Li et al. [118] used ZnO/Al2O3 as a gasoline desulfurization additive. They found that high-temperature hydrothermal conditions promoted the solid phase reaction between the additive and zeolite, leading to additive deactivation. The matrix has the effect of pre-cracking [119,120] and improving the mechanical properties of the catalyst required in industrial units [112,121], as well as reducing the damage of V to the RFCC catalysts, allowing it to retain more catalytic activity and micropores [15]. However, the active silica-alumina in the matrix tends to gradually lose surface area, porosity, and active sites under regenerator conditions, resulting in deactivation. USY zeolite catalyst based on Al2O3 shows excellent cracking activity and a low coking rate in n-hexadecane catalytic cracking [120,122]. During zeolite regeneration, Al2O3 traps vanadium that migrates to SiO2 and reduces the adverse effects of hydrothermal steam, so Al2O3 has a good hydrothermal regeneration ability for vanadium deposition catalysts. Besides, the Al2O3 traps nickel and inhibits its hydrogen transfer to reduce the coking rate and protect the zeolite activity. Currently, studies related to the interaction of matrix constituents with zeolites and the development of new matrices are still limited [121]. 3 Research process on anti-deactivation of zeolite catalysts 3.1 Loading modification Zeolite catalyst is an acid catalyst with negative charges on the framework, favorable for catalytic acid reactions such as cracking, dehydrogenation, dealkylation, and isomerization. In industry, loadings such as metals are often introduced on the surface and framework of zeolite, thereby changing the physical and chemical properties, providing new active sites for zeolite catalysts, and improving resistance to metal contaminants and coke formation. The loading modification can be divided into two types from the perspective of whether the loading affects the framework of zeolite catalysts: isomorphous substitution and non-isomorphous substitution. The former refers to atoms that initially existed in the zeolite framework being replaced by other atoms through in-situ synthesis and post treatment, forming new active sites and changing the catalytic performance of the catalyst; the latter mainly refers to the loadings attached to the zeolite surface or inside by impregnation, ion exchange, and mechanical mixing methods. 3.1.1 Non-isomorphous substitution modification The loading of RE on zeolite is beneficial for improving the resistance of the catalyst to metal contaminants [37] and increasing the stability and activity of the catalyst [123,124]. Studies show that RE ions can be polarized with water to generate protons to induce the formation of hydroxyl, which increases the amount of acid sites of the catalyst and the forces between Al and O in the zeolite and stabilize the catalyst structure [63]. Du [125] and Hunger et al. [126] believed that the transfer of RE ions into zeolite has three steps (see Eqs. 8, 9, and 10). First, RE ions exist as RE(H2O)n 3+ in the aqueous solution, and those located in the supercages are dehydrated to generate RE(OH)2+ during calcination and hydrothermal treatment. Then, RE ions migrate from supercages to sodalite cages [127,128]. Last, RE(OH)2+ cations react with oxygen to form RE oxides (RE2O3), spreading to the zeolite surface. (8) RE(H2O)n3+ → RE(OH)2++H++H2O (9) RE(OH)2+ (supercage) → RE(OH)2+ (sodalite cage) (10) 2RE(OH)2++O2 → RE2O3+H2O RE-loaded zeolite catalysts have increased stability, which may be due to the stable combination of RE into the cages with framework oxygen atoms inhibiting the removal of Al and Si from zeolite under hydrothermal conditions [63]. The moderate RE ion exchange can hydrolyze to form B acid sites, decrease the amount of strong and weak acid sites, and increase the proportion of medium acid sites (see Eqs. 11, and 12) [2,129]. However, exchange with a high concentration of RE ion solution will decrease acidity, which may be due to the formation of bridged hydroxyl groups (see Eq. 13) [63]. Studies have also shown that the B acidity of zeolite increases with the increasing ionic radius of RE atoms. The larger the ionic radius of RE is, the easier hydrolysis occurs [130,131]. Besides, Alkaline RE oxides such as La2O3 can neutralize vanadic acid to form RE vanadate, thereby inhibiting the rapid hydrolysis of the zeolite framework and V poisoning (see Eq. 14) [110]. (11) RE3++H2O → [RE(OH)]2++H+ (12) RE3++2 H2O → [RE(OH)2]++2 H+ (13) 2RE3++H2O → [RE−OH−RE)]5++H+ (14) RE2O3+2 H3VO4 → 2REVO4+3 H2O RE loading often uses the method of non-isomorphous substitution and needs to control its amount and loading location, or the zeolite may be negatively affected [132]. According to the crystallographic principle, if metal ions replace the framework Al in the zeolite crystal structure to form a stable tetrahedron [MO4], the radius ratio of MZ+ cation and O2- anion should be within the range of 0.225–0.414 [133,134], while in fact, the radius ratio is generally within the range of 0.530–1.437. Hence, making RE elements into the zeolite framework for isomorphous replacement is difficult. Chen et al. [135] used the impregnation modification method to introduce Ce and La into the zeolite. They found that they can increase the acid amount of the matrix and zeolite, improve the catalytic activity, but increase the coke yield, while P loading can reduce this drawback. The research shows that Ce polarizes strong acidic hydroxyl groups to increase B acid amount and decrease L acid amount [136]. Catalysts have different performances with different proportions of Ce and La [137]. It is found that high Ce content is favorable for improving the conversion rate of heavy oil, and high La content helps resist Ni and V poisoning [137]. Also, La increases the total acid amount of the zeolite catalyst to enhance catalyst nitrogen resistance [138]. Bai et al. [6] believed that RE inhibits dealumination by stabilizing the zeolite framework, resulting in the elongation of the coordinating bond between Al and O, which leads to the expansion of UCS of RE-exchanged zeolites. However, due to the high price of RE, which is contrary to the economic benefits of industrial catalysis, more scholars tend to choose transition metals, alkaline earth metals and other metals with good economic performance. Zr loading can improve the hydrothermal stability and heavy oil conversion rate of zeolite catalyst [7]. Besides, Liu et al. [7] also found that zeolite catalyst modified by ZrO2 has a high resistance to basic nitrogen. Shen et al. [139] used the USY zeolite catalyst loaded with alkaline earth metal Mg to crack heavy oil. The results showed that increasing the loading of Mg decreases the amount of acid sites on the zeolite surface, the coke yield, and the heavy oil conversion rate. Loading transition metals such as Co, Ni, Mo, and W helps remove heteroatoms and poisonous metals in heavy oil and makes zeolite catalysts have excellent decarbonization and hydrogenation properties [63]. There will be a synergistic effect between the metal sites and the acid sites after loading W and P on ZSM-5, which increases the light olefins yield. The P powerfully restrains the dehydrogenation activity of W, hence optimizing the product distribution [140]. However, the high metal loading blocks the zeolite pores, decreasing the catalyst activity. As shown in Fig. 3, the non-isomorphous substitution improves the anti-deactivation ability of zeolite catalyst to increase conversion rate and light oil selectivity in RFCC. Table 3 summarizes the heavy oil catalytic cracking effect of the non-isomorphous substitution modified catalysts. It can be seen from Table 3 that non-isomorphous substitution modification greatly improves the catalyst performance hence increasing conversion rate and light oil selectivity. Table 3 indicates that Y zeolite has been widely used in the RFCC. Its pore size generally reaches up to at least 0.76 nm and even reaches 1.3 nm or more at the intersection of pores [119], so the pore structure of Y zeolite fits RFCC. The research on the loadings is still in the development stage, considering the price and catalytic performance of the loadings, noble metals such as Au [141], non-metals such as P [135], alkaline earth metals such as Mg [139], and metal oxides such as Fe2O3 [142] are still less studied. 3.1.2 Isomorphous substitution modification The crystallographic principle shows that only a part of atoms can replace the atoms in the zeolite framework isomorphically [134]. At present, Scholars researched the isomorphous substitution of zeolite catalyst with Co [146], Ga [147], Ge [148], B [149], Ti [150], Fe [151], Zn [152], P [153], Zr [7]. Introducing heteroatoms into the zeolite framework changes zeolite catalysts’ thermal stability and acidity [153]. Some scholars found that using (NH4)2SiF6 for isomorphous substitution modification of zeolite has the effect of simultaneous dealumination and silicon supplementation, which decreases the amount of acid sites and generates more mesopores to improve the diffusion performance of zeolite [154]. Recently, some scholars prepared Y/ZrO2 composites with a micro-mesoporous hierarchical structure, which introduced Zr species into the framework of Y zeolite to form Zr-O-Si chemical bonds, protected the acid sites of zeolite and inhibited the coke deposition, compared with the catalyst prepared by mechanical mixing, the conversion of VGO increased by 1.78% [7]. Currently, the zeolite catalysts modified by isomorphous substitution are generally used for the catalytic reaction of light hydrocarbons, and few scholars have researched them in RFCC. 3.2 Regulation of particle size and structure During RFCC, the slow mass transfer of the zeolite micropores results in cracking products staying in zeolite crystals too long, leading to heavy oil cracking excessively, which promotes the reaction of coking and dehydrogenation [155] and also accelerates the metal poisoning [156] and affect the catalyst activity. The fundamental problem needed to be solved by reducing the negative effects of diffusion limitations in the micropores of zeolite catalysts. The small Thiele modulus means the minor diffusion limitations of zeolite catalysts [157]. Since the intrinsic rate coefficient is fixed for a given reaction and zeolite, shortening the diffusion length (L) and enhancing the effective diffusivity (Deff) in the zeolite pores are two basic strategies to reduce the diffusion limitations. The best way to achieve it is to increase the pore size and shorten the diffusion length of the micropores. In addition, the synthesis condition of large-pore zeolite is often harsh and expensive, and the synthesized zeolite has disadvantages of low acidity, low thermal stability, and low catalytic efficiency [158]. So, the main methods to reduce the diffusion limitations are decreasing the particle size and regulating the zeolite structure. 3.2.1 Particle size regulation In recent years, nano-zeolite has gotten continuous attention in the zeolite field. The nano-zeolite has properties of large specific surface area, abundant active sites, and high acidity, which causes its high catalytic activity [159]. In addition, the small diffusion limitation of reactants and products in nano-zeolite nanocrystals improves the reaction selectivity, effectively inhibits coke deposition, and increases the catalysts' lifetime [160]. The large specific surface area of nano-zeolite is favorable to RFCC due to the catalytic reaction of heavy oil macromolecules mostly occurring on the catalyst surface. However, the nano-zeolite generally has low thermal stability [161], which is negative [162]. Amini et al. [163] used nano-zeolite mixed with SiO2 to prepare a catalyst for heavy oil cracking and found a higher heavy oil conversion rate and gasoline selectivity than micro-zeolite and a lower coke yield. Karami et al. [164] prepared Y zeolite catalysts with different particle sizes for catalytic cracking of heavy oil, and the results show that the catalyst activity, external surface area, and accessible sites increased with decreasing particle size, and the catalyst with the smallest particle size exhibited the highest heavy oil conversion and lowest coke yield. The research of Gao et al. [165] shows that decreasing the zeolite particle size is favorable to improving the cracking activity and reducing the attrite index of catalyst while improving the cleanliness of gasoline. The yields of LPG and propylene increased by 0.41% and 0.08%, respectively. Fig. 12 [166] shows that with the decrease of zeolite catalyst particle size, the light oil yield increases, the coke yield decreases, and the conversion rate of heavy oil increases. This may be because smaller particle size leads to a larger percentage of external surface area and more acid sites on the zeolite surface. Therefore, the accessibility of heavy oil macromolecules is higher, and the secondary cracking reaction is inhibited. Nano-zeolite catalyst has a high preparation cost and low hydrothermal stability, so it is key to studying low-cost preparation methods and stability enhancement methods. 3.2.2 Structure regulation Structure regulation can change pore size, specific surface area, acidity distribution, and Si/Al ratio of zeolite catalysts, thereby adjusting the heat and mass transfer efficiency in the catalytic cracking process, which is of great significance to RFCC. Pore grading is an important means of achieving structure regulation, which can shorten the diffusion length of reactants and products, increase the Deff, and variably control the acidity distribution [158,167]. Zeolite can be divided into microporous (<2 nm), mesoporous (2–50 nm), and macroporous (>50 nm) zeolite according to pore size. Microporous zeolite has the advantages of strong acidity, high hydrothermal stability, and good selectivity for small molecular substances such as propylene [165], but its large diffusion resistance is not fit RFCC. Mesoporous zeolite has the advantages of high specific surface area, large pore size, fast mass transfer, and high resistance to coke deposition [164]. However, it has weak acidity, low hydrothermal stability, and low selectivity for small molecules substances with high added value. The kinetic diameter of heavy oil macromolecules is much larger than Y zeolite pore size [119,167], so pore grading is critical for optimizing RFCC product distribution and improving the catalyst ability of anti-deactivation [168,169]. As shown in Fig. 13, according to the formation process of zeolite, the synthesis methods of hierarchical pore structure include in-situ synthesis and post-treatment. In-situ synthesis refers to the direct formation of the hierarchical pore by controlling the growth conditions and introducing unstable sites during synthesizing zeolite catalysts, which mostly require templates [145,170]. The templating has a key influence on the hierarchical porous zeolite performance [171]. Jin et al. [145] prepared a series of meso-microporous Y zeolite catalysts by adjusting the amount of templating (TPOACl) to crack VGO. The result shows that the amount of mesopores increases with the increasing amount of templates. A significant increase in gasoline yields and reduction of coke and dry gas yields were achieved with the meso-microporous Y-derived catalyst compared with the classical Y-derived catalyst. Post-treatment refers to the treatment of the produced zeolite catalysts, including acid treatment (hydrochloric acid [172], nitric acid [173], oxalic acid [173]), alkali treatment (sodium hydroxide/tetrabutylammonium [174], tetramethylammonium hydroxide [163], sodium hydroxide [157,175,176]), hydrothermal treatment [177,178], the assembly (indirect synthesis of core-shell zeolite [179,180], direct synthesis of core-shell zeolite [181,182]). The acid treatment removes Al in zeolite catalysts, which directly affects the acid sites distribution and pore structure of zeolite catalysts [183]. The influence degree depends on the acid species and the acid concentration. A certain degree of dealumination can increase the catalytic activity [173]. Zhang et al. [144] treated USY zeolite with a mixed acid solution to clean its pores for the cracking of VGO and found that the USY zeolite catalyst treated with acid had higher catalytic performance and higher resistance to metal contamination compared with the unmodified catalyst. Alkali treatment mainly removes Si from the zeolite framework [184], hence adjusting the Si/Al ratio and acid sites distribution of zeolite [185]. Some scholars [163] prepared Y zeolite with different Si/Al ratios by alkali treatment (tetramethylammonium hydroxide, sodium hydroxide) to crack heavy oil and found the loss of specific surface area of catalysts and coke yield decreased with the increasing Si/Al ratio. Therefore, rational control of the catalyst Si/Al ratio and acid distribution is conducive to improving the product distribution and conversion rate of heavy oil cracking. Hydrothermal treatment is easier to dealuminate (mainly framework Al) compared with desiliconize [186], and Si replaces the removed framework Al hence forming secondary pores [187]. Assembly refers to the assembly of protozeolitic units or preformed solid materials such as silicates or aluminosilicates into mesoporous materials with nanocrystalline pore walls [181,188,189], which have excellent shape selectivity, acid distribution, and stability. Assembling zeolites with different properties invites multifunctional catalytic performance, which overcomes the shortcomings of a single zeolite. Studies [190] have found that heavy oil can be pre-cracked on the outer macro-mesopore zeolite shell. The cracked products enter the micro-nanopore zeolite core to undergo secondary cracking reactions. The core-shell structure effectively reduces the diffusion length of intermediate products, decreases coke yield, protects the acid sites, and improves the catalytic performance and hydrothermal stability of catalysts [190,191]. Liu et al. [191] synthesized core-shell Y zeolite catalysts with a commercial Y zeolite core and a polycrystalline shell composed of loosely aggregated Y nanocrystals, and the result verified that the large reactants can be pre-cracked on the accessible external surfaces and the pre-cracked products can be further deeply cracked by the strong acid sites in the micropores. Also, Many core-shell zeolites catalyst such as Al2O3 (shell)/Y zeolite (core) [192], ZSM-5 (core)/SAPO-5 (shell) [193] have been synthesized to hierarchically crack heavy oil. These core-shell zeolites have suitable structure and acidity, high resistance to coke deposition and metal poisoning, and a high conversion rate of heavy oil. Fig. 14 indicates that the heavy oil macromolecules can first generate some medium molecular weight compounds such as naphthalene ring compounds, long-chain olefins, and alkanes under the catalysis of Y zeolite, then, under the catalysis of ZSM-5 zeolite, these compounds undergo reactions such as bond breaking, dehydrogenation, and isomerization to produce some small molecular weight products such as short-chain alkanes, olefins, and aromatic hydrocarbons. So the conversion of heavy oil may be related to the shell, and the yield of light products is related to the core. The synergistic application of in-situ synthesis and post-treatment can efficiently regulate the catalyst structure, improving its catalytic performance and stability. Some scholars used acid and hydrothermal treatments to dealuminate Y zeolite, which effectively regulates the acid distribution of catalysts, improves the conversion rate of heavy oil and light products yield, and inhibits the coke formation and catalyst deactivation [194]. Lv [195] et al. prepared a hierarchically porous Y zeolite catalyst by templating and hydrothermal treatment for catalytic cracking of heavy tar and found that it had better catalytic performance and higher light aromatic yield compared with microporous catalyst. 3.3 Additives As mentioned above, use of additives is an important means of anti-deactivation of RFCC catalysts [2]. In RFCC, the additive's deactivation directly affects the performance of the zeolite components and the overall catalyst. However, to maintain the catalytic activity of catalysts, the additive's deactivation is unavoidable, even necessary. The additives generally exist alone or mechanically mixed with the catalysts, which can improve the stability, catalytic activity, and dispersibility of catalysts, inhibit zeolite poisoning and coke deposition, and decrease catalyst deactivation and the burden on the regenerator. Besides, they are used for pre-catalysis and secondary catalysis to improve the catalyst performance and remove some harmful atoms such as Ni and V. Some scholars [196] used LaBO3 (B = Co, Mn, and Fe) perovskite as an additive and HY catalyst to crack the cumene and found that the coke formation decreased. The additive also helped regenerate the catalyst. ZSM-5 zeolite as an additive was mixed with USY catalyst to crack residue, and the results show that the gasoline yield increased and coke formation decreased [197]. In conclusion, the components of the catalyst and additives affect each other, and the additive's deactivation mechanisms are different with different properties and functions. To avoid catalyst deactivation, combining or modifying additives is necessary according to the different RFCC feedstocks [198]. 3.4 Modification of other components in RFCC catalyst Zeolite mainly provides cracking activity, while other components (matrix, clay, binder) provide physical properties such as hardness and strength required for operation in industrial environment. Improving the attrition resistance of RFCC zeolite catalysts favor reducing effective particles loss, thus reducing catalysts consumption. The commonly used binders are AlPO4, silica sol, alumina sol, and pseudoboehmite [199,200]. However, these binders have many defects. Such as the pore volume of alumina sol is low, and the strength of pseudo-boehmite is weak. Zhang et al. [201] used HCl-treated kaolin to prepare a new porous binder. The AI of the catalyst prepared with this new binder is reduced by 0.6%, and the light oil yield is increased by 0.79%. Previous studies have shown that improving the attrition resistance of catalysts invites a compromise of catalytic performance [202]. However, Zhang et al. [203] prepared an in situ RFCC catalyst with high porosity and attrition resistance ability, and Y zeolite content (over 60%) by introducing a porosity enlarging agent into kaolin. Zheng et al. [204] synthesized wide-pore composite materials with high attrition resistance and high Y zeolite content (53.5%) by an in-situ technique using kaolin, palygorskite, and pseudoboehmite. The acid-modified kaolin prepared by Gao et al. has abundant meso-macro pores and good hydrothermal stability. Meanwhile, the AI of the catalyst decreases by 0.3% [205]. Li et al. [102] used alkali solution aided (ASA) activation approach to efficiently transform silicon and aluminum components in kaolin microspheres into active silica and alumina. The zeolite content is 22% higher than standard NaY and has excellent attrition resistance. 3.5 Machine learning assists RFCC catalyst design Machine learning (ML) is a technology that uses computers to analyze existing data, find out the patterns and characteristics of data, and make judgments and predictions [206]. It is widely used in various fields [206]. Generally, ML techniques include feature extraction, classification/clustering, and regression (see Fig. 15) [207]. Feature extraction methods such as Principal Component Analysis (PCA) [208], Independent Component Analysis (ICA) [209], and Multi-Dimensional Scaling (MDS) [210] are often used for dimensionality reduction, which transform the inherent information and trends in the original dataset into more meaningful form for further mathematical and statistical analysis. Classification/clustering methods like Support Vectors Machines (SVM) [211], Artificial Neural Networks (ANN) [212], Decision Trees (DT) [213], and Naive Bayes [214] are usually used to group data by similarity measure. The final class of ML techniques is regression, wherein the models develop underlying relations or correlations for a set of input-output data. Some common regression methods used in ML are Support Vector Regression (SVR) [215], Kernel Ridge Regression (KRR) [216], and Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) [217]. ML has achieved many valuable research results in catalyst design and screening [212,218,219]. As shown in Table 4, many studies show that the ML help effectively select the optimal catalyst for the complex chemical process [220]. Despite the differences in processes and catalysts, ML has demonstrated a powerful ability to assist catalyst design in various chemical fields. The increased target values mean that the optimal catalysts make the processes optimize. However, the application of ML tools in the field of RFCC is still at an early stage and very few literatures can be found [221]. RFCC unit modeling is a complex nonlinear problem [221–223]. Kurogi et al. [206] designed FCC catalysts by ML and multiobjective optimization. They used response surface methodology to establish a training set consisting of 1000 data points with varied catalyst compositions, feedstock properties, pseudo-equilibrium conditions, cracking performance test conditions as input parameters and the cracking test results as outputs. Finally, the optimal catalyst selected by the pareto front improved the gasoline yield by 2.7%. Yang et al. [221] developed a novel hybrid model integrating a deep neural network with a lumped kinetic model to predict the product yield of the FCC unit, and the model exhibited the best predictions for all evaluation criteria. The extreme learning machine (ELM) base learners proposed by Zhang et al. have excellent performance in predicting the coke production in FCC [224], which is meaningful for inhibiting coke formation and deposition of catalyst. Bram et al. [225] used ML to predict the FCC catalyst saturation level in the regenerator to reduce catalyst consumption, hence reducing catalyst deactivation, improving product yield and process efficiency. To prepare RFCC catalysts with high performance and anti-deactivation ability, starting from the feedstock composition, catalyst structure, reaction conditions, and product distribution, ML should be used to establish and optimize the RFCC prediction model. As shown in Fig. 16, the composition of heavy oil is complex, and the characteristics of zeolite catalyst deactivation caused by different feedstock components are different. Therefore, the mechanisms and characteristics of RFCC catalyst deactivation caused by different feedstocks should be gradually explored from model compounds to family components and then to heavy oil ("point-line-plane" method) to design targeted catalysts. Firstly, a training set is established based on a large amount of data obtained according to the "point-line-plane" method. On this basis, feedstock properties, reaction conditions, and catalyst parameters (e.g., Si/Al ratio, the type and content of zeolite/clay/additive/matrix/loadings, loading method, pore size distribution, and particle size) are taken as inputs. Then the experimental results include catalyst deactivation parameters (e.g., coke/metal/heteroatom deposition amounts, particle weight loss, pore structure variations) and product distribution parameters (light oil/coke/gas yield) as outputs. Finally, the catalyst's physical and chemical structure parameters can be optimized by machine learning algorithms (feature extraction, classification/clustering, and regression) for input-output data, thereby improving the anti-deactivation ability. Kinetic modeling is another alternative type of RFCC modeling, which mainly includes lumped models and molecular-level kinetic models [231]. The kinetic study plays an important role in determining the deactivation mechanisms and providing effective ways to prevent the rapid deactivation of the catalysts. In kinetic modeling, the effect of deactivation is incorporated by including the so-called deactivation function. Kinetic deactivation models can be categorized into two types. One is a nonselective deactivation model that assumes the deactivation of catalyst affects each one of the reactions in the reaction network similarly. The other is the selective deactivation model, in which catalyst deactivation is assumed to affect each reacting species and reactions in a complex reaction network with different manners and contributes to the different variations in product yield [232,233]. The former can fit well with the experimental data, and the cheaper computationally cost makes catalyst deactivation can be considered easily. The latter method is realistic. However, the model's complexity makes it inapplicable [233]. Therefore, most researchers focus on the nonselective deactivation model [234]. Kinetic deactivation modeling can predict and simulate the effect of feedstocks properties (e.g., the content of saturates, aromatics and resins, and distillation range) [235], catalyst/oil (C/O) ratio [236], catalyst's physiochemical properties (e.g., zeolite to matrix specific surface area ratio, total Bronsted to Lewis acid amount ratio, and zeolite UCS) [237], process variables (e.g., temperature, and slop flow) [235] on deactivation rate and degree of catalyst, hence instructing the synthesis of RFCC catalyst with high anti-deactivation ability. Several mathematical functions of RFCC deactivation kinetics are shown in Table 5. Most studies on RFCC deactivation kinetics usually only consider the effect of coking deactivation on the model. In recent years, some scholars have also considered the effect of aromatics adsorption and basic nitrogen poisoning (see Table 5). The coking deactivation modeling generally connects RFCC catalyst deactivation with coke deposited on catalyst (COC) [238] or time on stream (TOS) [239]. In previous studies, the TOS model was mainly used because the mass of coke deposited on the catalyst was challenging to measure accurately. The coking deactivation kinetics model based on TOS developed by Corella et al. [240] showed that the function order decreases with the contact time. Cesar et al. think that coke formation in FCC is a second-order reaction, and active site amounts decrease exponentially with increasing coke content [236]. Their deactivation model based on TOS showed that the optimum C/O ratio is 2.5–3.75. Above 3.75, more coke formation invites the decreased strong acid site amounts and increased diffusional limitations, decreasing desirable product yield. However, the simulation result of Galina et al. [235] showed that although coke deposited on the catalyst increased with increasing C/O ratio, its content decreased, resulting in a rise in average catalyst activity. The Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) model usually is chosen to calculate the effect of aromatics adsorption. As described above, basic nitrogen can promote coking and reduce catalyst activity in various forms. Therefore, it is necessary to introduce the deactivation function of basic nitrogen poisoning into RFCC kinetic modeling when the basic nitrogen species contents in feedstocks are large [241]. 4 Regeneration of spent RFCC catalysts The regeneration methods of S-Cat mainly include coke burning regeneration, chemical regeneration, and magnetic separation [244,245], among which only coke burning regeneration has been widely applied in industry. Currently, chemical regeneration and magnetic separation are still being studied on a laboratory scale. 4.1 Coke burning regeneration The coke burning regeneration means heating zeolite catalysts at a high temperature in the air. It is the most widely used method to regenerate S-Cat in refineries, including in-situ and ex-situ regeneration. Controlling the regeneration temperature can remove the coke deposited on zeolite catalysts, clean the blocked pores, and decrease the strong metal-support interaction. The temperature should not be too high, or it will promote the metal-support interaction, generating low active species and decreasing the catalyst activity [246]. 4.2 Chemical regeneration The chemical regeneration method first uses roasting to pretreat the S-Cat and then uses chemical reagents to react with S-Cat to remove heavy metals such as Ni, and V, which clear the blocked pores and recover the catalytic activity of the catalyst. Some scholars have used pickling, carbonylation-chlorination, sulfidation-oxidation, and other methods to remove the Ni, V, and Fe on the zeolite to recover the catalyst performance [244,247–250]. The moderate acid treatment can effectively remove Ni and Fe from S-Cat and improve the crystallinity of catalysts. However, it can increase the Si/Al ratio and remove the RE metals, decreasing the catalyst acidity and activity [248]. Some scholars used an organic coordination method to regenerate zeolite catalysts, which can increase the removal rates of Ni and V up to 30%, and the crystallinity of zeolite catalysts was improved, the pore structure was optimized, and the conversion rate of crude was increased [244]. Recently, the SiCl4 co-calcination regeneration method to recover the activity of zeolite catalysts has appeared [245]. In addition to traditional chemical reagents, the study has found that hydrogen pretreatment can decrease the hydrogenation activities of the contaminant metals, thereby significantly decreasing the coking amount and effectively promoting the regeneration and recycling of the S-Cat [30]. 4.3 Magnetic separation The magnetic separation method means the strong magnetic field separates the catalyst with high metal poisoning and the catalyst with low metal poisoning based on their different magnetic inductance, thereby saving the amount of RFCC catalyst and maintaining the high activity of the catalyst during the RFCC process [251]. The catalysts can be recycled after the separation, but the recovery rate of magnetic separation should be controlled in a suitable range. The high recovery rate lowers the reaction activity and makes catalysts remove the metals and regenerate again tricky [252]. The force law of magnetic particles in the magnetic field is shown in Eq. (15), where Fm represents the magnetic force, C is a constant, X is the magnetic susceptibility of a paramagnetic substance, V is the volume of the particle, and H and Dh are the magnetic field strength and its gradient at the location of the particle, respectively. The separation degree can be controlled by characterizing and controlling the particle size of the S-Cat and the magnetic strength [253]. (15) FmC×X×V×H×Dh 5 Conclusions and outlook Fig. 17 summarizes the relationships between product yield, product distribution, catalyst deactivation and catalyst properties in RFCC. In a heterogeneous RFCC reaction, heavy oil molecules pass through the multi-scale pore network (from micrometers to nanometers) of catalyst particles and crack at different active sites to produce different product molecules. Therefore, the species migration in catalysts depends on the connectivity and permeability of the catalysts' hierarchical pore network. Heavy oil molecules are difficult to directly enter the pores of zeolite catalysts for acid catalytic cracking. Most catalytic cracking reactions first happen on the surface of zeolite catalysts, so increasing pore size is helpful to improve the conversion rate of heavy oil. Generally, the larger the pore size, the less carbon deposition and the fewer active sites be covered, but this is not absolute because the product distribution of the heavy oil is also determined by the acidity of the catalyst, including acid amount, acid strength, and acid species. Increasing acid amount is favorable to improving activity, hydrogen transfer performance, and hydrothermal stability of the catalyst. Reasonable regulation of acid distribution can effectively inhibit coke deposition, structure collapse, and poisoning of catalysts. Hierarchical pore structure increases the conversion rate of heavy oil and the yield of light oil products and decreases the coke deposition of the catalyst. Decreasing zeolite particle size can significantly decrease coke formation hence inhibiting the loss of active sites and pore blockage, also increasing conversion and light oil yield. However, the catalyst with a small particle size or large pore size has low hydrothermal stability, which easily causes structure collapse. It is not conducive to the recycling of the catalyst. Therefore, it is necessary to reasonably regulate the catalyst's pore structure, particle size, and Si/Al ratio. Loadings, additives, and matrix are important to the anti-deactivation of RFCC catalysts. The matrix and zeolite with large surface area, high pore volume, and abundant surface acidity promote the diffusion and pre-cracking of heavy oil molecules in the RFCC catalyst and inhibit the coking deactivation of zeolite. The species and amount of loadings significantly affect the hydrothermal stability of zeolite, which further affects UCS. The UCS directly affects catalyst activity, product distribution, hydrogen transfer reaction rate, and hydrogen transfer reaction rate affects the coke formation and deactivation of the catalyst. As the demand for light oil and propylene increases, the need for highly active, stable, and selective zeolite catalysts will continue to increase. However, the complex composition of heavy crude poses a challenge in designing zeolite catalysts with high resistance to deactivation. The properties of feedstock and RFCC processes indirectly influence the structure and composition of the catalyst. Therefore, our study proposed that to prepare targeted RFCC catalysts with high performance and anti-deactivation ability, starting from the feedstock composition, the catalyst's structure, reaction conditions, product distribution, and others, and using ML to build and optimize the RFCC prediction model may be an effective solution. Nano-zeolite has abundant active sites, and the diffusion restriction of reactants and products is small. However, the problem of hydrothermal deactivation of nano-zeolite remains to be solved. Using the bottom-up or top-down method to prepare hierarchically porous zeolite catalysts and simultaneously optimizing the type and amount of loading species can significantly improve the anti-deactivation ability of catalysts to improve the yield of light oil and the conversion rate of feedstocks. In addition, exploring low-cost zeolite catalyst preparation and regeneration methods is of great significance to industry and the environment. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic cracking is one of the most important refining processes used in the petrochemical industry, in which the highly active zeolite catalyst is the key to heavy oil catalytic cracking. However, heavy oil deactivates zeolite catalysts easily, which is not conducive to raw material conversion and quality improvement. With the increase of industrial capacity, the output of spent catalysts is also increasing year by year, which puts forward higher requirements for the catalyst deactivation mechanism and regeneration process. In this paper, the deactivation mechanisms of zeolite catalyst in heavy oil catalytic cracking were clarified, and the anti-deactivation methods of zeolite catalyst, such as modification, structure regulation, use of additives, and machine learning assists in catalyst design were summarized, and the corresponding catalyst regeneration methods were proposed. It is a hot topic to apply the pore classification and nanocrystallization of catalyst, which provides a reference for the application of heavy oil catalytic cracking catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: Anti-deactivation of zeolite catalysts for residue fluid catalytic cracking
